Hardware Lab

Hardware products in development

From experimental prototypes to production-minded embedded systems, focused on durability, clarity, and real interaction.

Why this lab exists

Most hardware demos look exciting in short clips, but fall apart in daily use. The focus here is different: stable firmware, predictable behavior, maintainable module architecture, and interaction models that still feel good after months. Keero is the primary vehicle for that approach.

Modular by design Local-first processing Behavior + firmware co-design

Keero Device

A modular, voice-first robotics platform built on ESP32-S3. Keero combines local audio intelligence, expressive state logic, and extensible hardware modules into one cohesive system.

  • ESP32-S3
  • PlatformIO
  • C++
  • Audio DSP
  • MCP Tools
Flagship build Open project

Canarin Garage Electronics

Custom moto-electronics systems: harness architecture, ignition integration, and instrument control stacks designed for reliability in real operating conditions.

  • Wiring Architecture
  • Ignition
  • Instrumentation
Workshop R&D Open project

Keero module strategy

The Keero device line is being built with module-strip compatibility in mind, including ecosystems similar to SparkBot-style expansion. That means easier prototyping, faster replacement cycles, and cleaner upgrades without redesigning the whole robot each iteration.

  • • Core compute + audio board as stable base layer
  • • Emotion and behavior runtime inspired by Clawino brain concepts
  • • Planned WireClaw all-in-one convergence for unified capabilities
  • • Practical module expansion for sensors, motion, and interaction blocks
